elements.content: Tunable inorganic nodes and modifiable organic linkers enable designable functionality to come to fruition in new-type porous hybrid materials, namely metal–organic frameworks (MOFs). By using viologen-functionalized m-benzenedicarboxylate as an organic linker, a terbium-organic framework embedded with asymmetric viologen species has been constructed. The reversible photochromism from bright yellow to dark green is implemented due to the favorable spatial stack of the electron donor and acceptor. The photochromic component of the organic linkers can modulate the luminescence of the tetranuclear terbium cluster under irradiation of UV light, which is defined as photoluminescence switching behavior. The different protonation levels of uncoordinated N atoms with varying pH enable the MOF as a potential fluorescent pH sensor. Thus, multiphotofunctionality, viz. photoluminescence, photochromism as well as the derivate fluorescent response to irradiation and pH have been combined in the Tb-MOF, which is the first example in the viologen-based photochromic hybrid materials.
elements.clean_text: Tunable inorganic nodes and modifiable organic linkers enable designable functionality to come to fruition in new-type porous hybrid materials, namely metal-organic frameworks (MOFs). By using viologen-functionalized m-benzenedicarboxylate as an organic linker, a terbium-organic framework embedded with asymmetric viologen species has been constructed. The reversible photochromism from bright yellow to dark green is implemented due to the favorable spatial stack of the electron donor and acceptor. The photochromic component of the organic linkers can modulate the luminescence of the tetranuclear terbium cluster under irradiation of UV light, which is defined as photoluminescence switching behavior. The different protonation levels of uncoordinated N atoms with varying pH enable the MOF as a potential fluorescent pH sensor. Thus, multiphotofunctionality, viz. photoluminescence, photochromism as well as the derivate fluorescent response to irradiation and pH have been combined in the Tb-MOF, which is the first example in the viologen-based photochromic hybrid materials.

elements.content: The study of metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) has skyrocketed during recent decades because of their fascinating network topologies and intriguing properties. Numerous organic linkers have been designed to make target MOFs with specific geometric structures and physical properties. Application-oriented MOFs can be obtained using appropriate metal clusters (SBUs) and functional organic linkers as building blocks. The 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid and its derivatives become conspicuous and indispensible in constructing multiple coordination polymers. Additionally, viologen-functionalized materials, including polymers, nanocrystals, as well as various composites, display a high potential for applications in a range of optoelectronic and photochemical devices, smart windows, and new displays and so forth. Consequently, they have received great attention in the fields of physics, chemistry, and materials science. The study of viologen in the crystalline state has become more interesting since the first discovery of the crystal structures before and after irradiation by Guo’s group. Using the viologen species modified 5-position of m-benzenedicarboxylate is expected to obtain more novel structural MOFs with specific photofunctionality.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

The study of metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) has skyrocketed during recent decades because of their fascinating network topologies and intriguing properties. Numerous organic linkers have been designed to make target MOFs with specific geometric structures and physical properties. Application-oriented MOFs can be obtained using appropriate metal clusters (SBUs) and functional organic linkers as building blocks. The 1,3-benzenedicarboxylic acid and its derivatives become conspicuous and indispensible in constructing multiple coordination polymers. Additionally, viologen-functionalized materials, including polymers, nanocrystals, as well as various composites, display a high potential for applications in a range of optoelectronic and photochemical devices, smart windows, and new displays and so forth. Consequently, they have received great attention in the fields of physics, chemistry, and materials science. The study of viologen in the crystalline state has become more interesting since the first discovery of the crystal structures before and after irradiation by Guo's group. Using the viologen species modified 5-position of m-benzenedicarboxylate is expected to obtain more novel structural MOFs with specific photofunctionality.

elements.content: Recently, luminescent MOFs have been used for chemical sensing, such as small molecules, metal ions, and explosives. Nevertheless, only a few MOFs have been explored as fluorescent pH sensors. Among them, MOFs with pH-dependent fluorescent ligands or postloaded pH-sensitive fluorescent dyes are excellent examples for pH sensing. And the reported Eu3+-based MOFs have a linear response near a pH value of 7.0. It is well-known that pyridyl nitrogen atoms can undergo protonation under acidic conditions, which provides an opportunity to incorporate a pyridyl unit in the fluorescent MOFs for pH sensing.
elements.clean_text: Recently, luminescent MOFs have been used for chemical sensing, such as small molecules, metal ions, and explosives. Nevertheless, only a few MOFs have been explored as fluorescent pH sensors. Among them, MOFs with pH-dependent fluorescent ligands or postloaded pH-sensitive fluorescent dyes are excellent examples for pH sensing. And the reported Eu3+-based MOFs have a linear response near a pH value of 7.0. It is well-known that pyridyl nitrogen atoms can undergo protonation under acidic conditions, which provides an opportunity to incorporate a pyridyl unit in the fluorescent MOFs for pH sensing.

elements.content: Herein, we design an organic ligand based on m-benzenedicarboxylate, namely, 1-(3,5-dicarboxybenzyl)-4,4′-bipyridinium chloride (H2L+Cl–), in which the asymmetric viologen unit ligated at the 5-position acts as a photochromic part and one free pyridyl nitrogen atom is pendent. Moreover, lanthanide ions with excellent luminescent features have stronger affinity with carboxylate oxygen atoms than the pyridyl nitrogen atom. So, terbium­(III) ions are chosen as the fluorophor and metal nodes with H2L+Cl– to construct a Tb-MOF. As expected, in the compound, carboxylate oxygen atoms and terbium­(III) ions form tetranuclear luminescent metal clusters, and the asymmetric viologen moieties with free N atoms are successfully embedded in the cavity of the porous framework. The reversible photochromism from bright yellow to dark green is implemented due to the presence of viologen species and favorable spatial stack of the electron donor and acceptor. Furthermore, electron/energy transfer processes occur between inorganic fluorescent SBUs and organic photochromic component (Figure ), thus leading to the modulation of the emission intensity by irradiation. In the meantime, the protonation of free N atoms of pyridine groups at different pH can influence the luminescence intensity of the framework. In all, photochromism, photomodulated fluorescence and luminescent pH sensing are achieved in the Tb-MOF. As far as we know, the Tb-MOF is the first MOF-based material that possesses such multiple photofunctionality, which is not independent of one another, but is correlated.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we design an organic ligand based on m-benzenedicarboxylate, namely, 1-(3,5-dicarboxybenzyl)-4,4'-bipyridinium chloride (H2L+Cl-), in which the asymmetric viologen unit ligated at the 5-position acts as a photochromic part and one free pyridyl nitrogen atom is pendent. Moreover, lanthanide ions with excellent luminescent features have stronger affinity with carboxylate oxygen atoms than the pyridyl nitrogen atom. So, terbium(III) ions are chosen as the fluorophor and metal nodes with H2L+Cl- to construct a Tb-MOF. As expected, in the compound, carboxylate oxygen atoms and terbium(III) ions form tetranuclear luminescent metal clusters, and the asymmetric viologen moieties with free N atoms are successfully embedded in the cavity of the porous framework. The reversible photochromism from bright yellow to dark green is implemented due to the presence of viologen species and favorable spatial stack of the electron donor and acceptor. Furthermore, electron/energy transfer processes occur between inorganic fluorescent SBUs and organic photochromic component (Figure ), thus leading to the modulation of the emission intensity by irradiation. In the meantime, the protonation of free N atoms of pyridine groups at different pH can influence the luminescence intensity of the framework. In all, photochromism, photomodulated fluorescence and luminescent pH sensing are achieved in the Tb-MOF. As far as we know, the Tb-MOF is the first MOF-based material that possesses such multiple photofunctionality, which is not independent of one another, but is correlated.

elements.content: Energy transfer and electron transfer in the Tb-MOF.
elements.clean_text: 1  Energy transfer and electron transfer in the Tb-MOF.

elements.content: Bright yellow crystals of Tb-MOF are built by a solvothermal reaction of H2L+Cl– and Tb­(NO3)3·6H2O in the mixture of water and acetonitrile (1:2) in 140 °C. Tb-MOF crystallizes in the high symmetry cubic space group I4̅3d (Table S1, , SI). The compound is a cationic framework, in which the highly disordered charge-balancing anions and solvent molecules are removed by SQUEEZE program. According to the results of the elemental analysis and ion chromatography analysis, the crystal was formulated as {[Tb4(μ3–OH)4L3·(H2O)7]­Cl0.63·(NO3)4.37·3H2O} n . Tb1 with the site occupancy factor of 1/3 is bound by seven oxygen atoms of three coordinated μ3–OH groups (O5, O5#1, and O5#2), three carboxylic groups (O1, O1#1, and O1#2) of three distinct ligands and one coordinated water molecule, completing a distorted capped-octahedral coordination sphere. Tb2 with distorted trigonal dodecahedron geometry is surrounded by eight oxygen atoms of three coordinated μ3–OH groups (O5, O5#1, and O8), three oxygen atoms (O2, O3#3, and O4#4) from three bidentate carboxylate groups and two coordinated water molecules. Each ligand bonds to four terbium­(III) ions through carboxylate oxygen atoms and one μ3–OH bridges three terbium­(III) ions. As a result, tetranuclear [Tb4(μ3–OH)4]8+ SBU is connected with three ligands to form a three-bladed paddlewheel structure ( Figure S1). As a whole, a similar configuration can be observed along any crystallographic axis (a,b,c) due to the high symmetry cubic space group. The 3D structural Tb-MOF is viewed as a 2-fold interpenetrated (10,3)-a architecture, containing two sets of structurally identical 3D nets (with the same metal–ligand connectivity mode) with different handedness. Viewed down the c axis, a set of chiral net involves two kinds of unequal helical chains, namely one big left-handed helix and a small right-handed helix (Figure a,b). They possess the same long pitches and are made up of tetranuclear terbium units and the V-shaped bridging ligands, but include eight and four tetranuclear SBUs respectively ( Figure S2). Moreover, these two types of helices are joined together by two tetranuclear terbium SBUs. Thus, one big left-handed helix is fused with four adjacent small right-handed helices, and vice versa, the small one joined hands with four neighboring large helices. If the tetranuclear terbium cluster was considered as a three-connected nonplanar node and two L2– ligands linking the same clusters were looked at as a linker, then the overall structure of Tb-MOF can be simplified as a 3-connected (10,3)-a (srs) network with a point (Schläfli) symbol of 103 (Figure c,d), which is a classical chiral topology net in crystalline motifs. However, this network in MOFs is usually obtained from 3-connected organic nodes, and that based on a 2-connected ligand is rare. So, the cubic and centrosymmetric structure of Tb-MOF is obtained by two inversion-symmetry-related nets with different chirality interpenetration (Figure e).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Structural Characterization

Bright yellow crystals of Tb-MOF are built by a solvothermal reaction of H2L+Cl- and Tb(NO3)3⋅6H2O in the mixture of water and acetonitrile (1:2) in 140 °C. Tb-MOF crystallizes in the high symmetry cubic space group I4̅3d (Table S1, , SI). The compound is a cationic framework, in which the highly disordered charge-balancing anions and solvent molecules are removed by SQUEEZE program. According to the results of the elemental analysis and ion chromatography analysis, the crystal was formulated as {[Tb4(μ3-OH)4L3⋅(H2O)7]Cl0.63⋅(NO3)4.37⋅3H2O} n . Tb1 with the site occupancy factor of 1/3 is bound by seven oxygen atoms of three coordinated μ3-OH groups (O5, O5#1, and O5#2), three carboxylic groups (O1, O1#1, and O1#2) of three distinct ligands and one coordinated water molecule, completing a distorted capped-octahedral coordination sphere. Tb2 with distorted trigonal dodecahedron geometry is surrounded by eight oxygen atoms of three coordinated μ3-OH groups (O5, O5#1, and O8), three oxygen atoms (O2, O3#3, and O4#4) from three bidentate carboxylate groups and two coordinated water molecules. Each ligand bonds to four terbium(III) ions through carboxylate oxygen atoms and one μ3-OH bridges three terbium(III) ions. As a result, tetranuclear [Tb4(μ3-OH)4]8+ SBU is connected with three ligands to form a three-bladed paddlewheel structure ( Figure S1). As a whole, a similar configuration can be observed along any crystallographic axis (a,b,c) due to the high symmetry cubic space group. The 3D structural Tb-MOF is viewed as a 2-fold interpenetrated (10,3)-a architecture, containing two sets of structurally identical 3D nets (with the same metal-ligand connectivity mode) with different handedness. Viewed down the c axis, a set of chiral net involves two kinds of unequal helical chains, namely one big left-handed helix and a small right-handed helix (Figure a,b). They possess the same long pitches and are made up of tetranuclear terbium units and the V-shaped bridging ligands, but include eight and four tetranuclear SBUs respectively ( Figure S2). Moreover, these two types of helices are joined together by two tetranuclear terbium SBUs. Thus, one big left-handed helix is fused with four adjacent small right-handed helices, and vice versa, the small one joined hands with four neighboring large helices. If the tetranuclear terbium cluster was considered as a three-connected nonplanar node and two L2- ligands linking the same clusters were looked at as a linker, then the overall structure of Tb-MOF can be simplified as a 3-connected (10,3)-a (srs) network with a point (Schläfli) symbol of 103 (Figure c,d), which is a classical chiral topology net in crystalline motifs. However, this network in MOFs is usually obtained from 3-connected organic nodes, and that based on a 2-connected ligand is rare. So, the cubic and centrosymmetric structure of Tb-MOF is obtained by two inversion-symmetry-related nets with different chirality interpenetration (Figure e).

elements.content: (a) The adjacent left-handed and right-handed helical chains generated by the SBU and m-benzenedicarboxylic acid units. (b) A set of chiral interpenetrating nets viewed down the c axis. (c) A set of chiral (10,3)-a network. (d) The 3-connected tetranuclear [Tb4(μ3–OH)4]-based SBU. (e) The 2-fold interpenetration of two different chiral (10,3)-a nets.

(e) The 2-fold interpenetration of two different chiral (10,3)-a nets.

elements.content: (a) Time-dependent UV–visible diffuse-reflectance of Tb-MOF upon light irradiation. The inset shows photographic images of the photochromic effects. (b) Time-dependent room-temperature ESR spectra of Tb-MOF upon light irradiation.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Time-dependent UV-visible diffuse-reflectance of Tb-MOF upon light irradiation. The inset shows photographic images of the photochromic effects. (b) Time-dependent room-temperature ESR spectra of Tb-MOF upon light irradiation.

elements.content: Similar to other viologen-based compounds, Tb-MOF shows an efficient photochromic transformation from bright yellow to dark green in answer to sunlight or xenon lamp, as depicted in Figure a. The above process is completely reversible and the colored photoproduct can be decolored in 1 day in the dark or heated to 120 °C for 1 h in air. There is not any obvious loss of photochromic properties even after eight coloring/bleaching cycles. Concomitantly, the time-dependent solid-state diffuse reflectance spectrum is correlated with the photochromic behavior upon irradiation with a 300 W xenon lamp. As shown in Figure a, two new adsorption peaks centered at 404 and 617 nm appear, and their intensities rise with the duration of irradiation, which presumably arise from the production of the viologen radical. It is common knowledge that the room temperature ESR signal of terbium ions cannot be observed as a result of the fast spin–lattice relaxation rate, which cannot interfere with the detection of viologen radical under irradiation of UV light. So the room-temperature ESR spectra of Tb-MOFs are recorded to further examine the generation of free radicals under UV light. The yellow Tb-MOF sample shows ESR-silence before irradiation, but presents a single resonance at g = 2.0041, akin to the value of a free electron (2.0023) after UV irradiation, and its intensity increases with irradiation time (Figure b), indicating that the paramagnetic center of the colored sample at room temperature should be a viologen radical.
elements.clean_text:
Photochromism

Similar to other viologen-based compounds, Tb-MOF shows an efficient photochromic transformation from bright yellow to dark green in answer to sunlight or xenon lamp, as depicted in Figure a. The above process is completely reversible and the colored photoproduct can be decolored in 1 day in the dark or heated to 120 °C for 1 h in air. There is not any obvious loss of photochromic properties even after eight coloring/bleaching cycles. Concomitantly, the time-dependent solid-state diffuse reflectance spectrum is correlated with the photochromic behavior upon irradiation with a 300 W xenon lamp. As shown in Figure a, two new adsorption peaks centered at 404 and 617 nm appear, and their intensities rise with the duration of irradiation, which presumably arise from the production of the viologen radical. It is common knowledge that the room temperature ESR signal of terbium ions cannot be observed as a result of the fast spin-lattice relaxation rate, which cannot interfere with the detection of viologen radical under irradiation of UV light. So the room-temperature ESR spectra of Tb-MOFs are recorded to further examine the generation of free radicals under UV light. The yellow Tb-MOF sample shows ESR-silence before irradiation, but presents a single resonance at g = 2.0041, akin to the value of a free electron (2.0023) after UV irradiation, and its intensity increases with irradiation time (Figure b), indicating that the paramagnetic center of the colored sample at room temperature should be a viologen radical.

elements.content: The unchanged PXRD and IR data before and after irradiation ( Figures S4 and S5), illustrate that the photochromism is unrelated to photoinduced isomerization or photolysis. Thus, the photochromism of Tb-MOF probably originates from an electron-transfer process. In contrast, the organic ligand H2L+Cl– only demonstrates adsorption in ultraviolet range and does not possess the photochromic behavior ( Figure S6). Therefore, the photochromic behavior in Tb-MOF may be related to its crystallographic structure. As shown in Figure , the distances between carboxylate O1, O2, and O1′ atoms of m-benzenedicarboxylate and the N1 atom of each pyridinium ring range from 3.42 to 3.61 Å. Therefore, the photochromic process should originate from the free radical generation of viologen units under irradition.
elements.clean_text: The unchanged PXRD and IR data before and after irradiation ( Figures S4 and S5), illustrate that the photochromism is unrelated to photoinduced isomerization or photolysis. Thus, the photochromism of Tb-MOF probably originates from an electron-transfer process. In contrast, the organic ligand H2L+Cl- only demonstrates adsorption in ultraviolet range and does not possess the photochromic behavior ( Figure S6). Therefore, the photochromic behavior in Tb-MOF may be related to its crystallographic structure. As shown in Figure , the distances between carboxylate O1, O2, and O1' atoms of m-benzenedicarboxylate and the N1 atom of each pyridinium ring range from 3.42 to 3.61 Å. Therefore, the photochromic process should originate from the free radical generation of viologen units under irradition.

elements.content: Distance and orientation between the donor (oxygen atoms of ligands) and acceptor (N1 of bpy) in Tb-MOF. Distances are in angstrom (Å).
elements.clean_text: 4  Distance and orientation between the donor (oxygen atoms of ligands) and acceptor (N1 of bpy) in Tb-MOF. Distances are in angstrom (Å).

elements.content: The luminescence excitation spectrum of Tb-MOF is investigated under the typical emission (542 nm) of the terbium­(III) ion ( Figure S7). A broad band centered at 336 nm should be put down to the transition arising from the ligands and one sharp peak at 485 nm is identified as 7F6 → 5D4 transition of terbium­(III) center. In the emission spectrum under excitation at 336 nm, the peaks located at 486, 542, 580, 619, 648, 666, and 677 nm that are respectively assigned to 5D4 → 7FJ with J = 6–0 transitions of terbium­(III) ion. Under UV light, the fluorescence emission intensity (542 nm) decreases as irradiation time increases, and reaches 15% of the starting value after 25 min (Figure ), accompanied by the sample color deepening as well as its absorption bands broadening and strengthening. Moreover, the experiment of fluorescent emission changes for the sample on alternate excitation by photo irradiation with UV light and heated at 120 °C over eight cycles in air has been performed. As shown in Figure , Tb-MOF has good reversibility for at least eight cycles. Thus, the photochromic reactions of Tb-MOF are coupled with a reversible fluorescence change. This photomodulated fluorescence in MOFs incorporating both fluorescent and photochromic component is relatively scarce. Because the emission bands of the luminescent components are overlapped with the absorption bands of the colored photoproduct ( Figure S8), intramolecular energy transfer from the excitation state of terbium­(III) to the colored state of the ligands may be responsible for the strong fluorescence quenching.
elements.clean_text:
Photomodulated Fluorescence

The luminescence excitation spectrum of Tb-MOF is investigated under the typical emission (542 nm) of the terbium(III) ion ( Figure S7). A broad band centered at 336 nm should be put down to the transition arising from the ligands and one sharp peak at 485 nm is identified as 7F6 → 5D4 transition of terbium(III) center. In the emission spectrum under excitation at 336 nm, the peaks located at 486, 542, 580, 619, 648, 666, and 677 nm that are respectively assigned to 5D4 → 7FJ with J = 6-0 transitions of terbium(III) ion. Under UV light, the fluorescence emission intensity (542 nm) decreases as irradiation time increases, and reaches 15% of the starting value after 25 min (Figure ), accompanied by the sample color deepening as well as its absorption bands broadening and strengthening. Moreover, the experiment of fluorescent emission changes for the sample on alternate excitation by photo irradiation with UV light and heated at 120 °C over eight cycles in air has been performed. As shown in Figure , Tb-MOF has good reversibility for at least eight cycles. Thus, the photochromic reactions of Tb-MOF are coupled with a reversible fluorescence change. This photomodulated fluorescence in MOFs incorporating both fluorescent and photochromic component is relatively scarce. Because the emission bands of the luminescent components are overlapped with the absorption bands of the colored photoproduct ( Figure S8), intramolecular energy transfer from the excitation state of terbium(III) to the colored state of the ligands may be responsible for the strong fluorescence quenching.

elements.content: Luminescence spectral changes (λex = 336 nm) of Tb-MOF after irradiation with UV light at 0, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 min. The inset shows the modulation of the fluorescence intensity at 542 nm due to alternating UV irradiation and heating treatment.
elements.clean_text: 5  Luminescence spectral changes (λex = 336 nm) of Tb-MOF after irradiation with UV light at 0, 5, 10, 15, 20, and 25 min. The inset shows the modulation of the fluorescence intensity at 542 nm due to alternating UV irradiation and heating treatment.

elements.content: To our knowledge, the stability of MOFs in different chemical environments is important for sensing applications. So far, MOFs that can maintain frameworks in acidic or basic conditions are quite rare. The Tb-MOF remains intact in aqueous solutions with pH ranging from 2 to 7 (Figure a), which provides the possibility for a pH sensor. Since the pendent pyridyl group can be easily protonated, we examine how the pH influences the fluorescence of the luminescent backbone. The crystals of Tb-MOF are ground, and the powdered samples are incubated in HCl aqueous solutions with pH ranging from 7 to 2. As shown in Figure b, the solid-state emission intensity of the acid-treated samples gradually decreased in acidic conditions and has a linear response (R 2 = 0.9917) to the pH from 2–7 and the highest value was obtained with pH = 7 solution. The fluorescence sensitivity to the pH could result from the pendent pyridyl groups in the framework. The protonation of the nitrogen atom of these pyridine units would change their electron withdrawing ability, which may be responsible for the decrease of intensity of luminescence at low pH. To further explore the possible mechanism, the ion chromatography of the hydrochloric acid-treated solid-state samples is measured. In the initial samples, Cl– and NO3 – ions as guest anions balance the charges of the cationic framework. The results of ion chromatography revealed the gradual increase of Cl– ions and almost invariable content of NO3 – ions in hydrochloric acid-treated solid-state samples with pH ranging from 7 to 2 (Table ). For hydrochloric acid-treated samples, according to the electric neutrality principle, the protonation of the pendent pyridyl group demand for extra anions (Cl–) are being included in the framework from the hydrochloric solution. In other words, the increased Cl– and the invariable NO3 – in acid-treated samples suggested that the protons are captured by pyridyl nitrogen atoms in HCl solutions, which in turn influence the fluorescence of the framework.
elements.clean_text:
Luminescent pH Sensing

To our knowledge, the stability of MOFs in different chemical environments is important for sensing applications. So far, MOFs that can maintain frameworks in acidic or basic conditions are quite rare. The Tb-MOF remains intact in aqueous solutions with pH ranging from 2 to 7 (Figure a), which provides the possibility for a pH sensor. Since the pendent pyridyl group can be easily protonated, we examine how the pH influences the fluorescence of the luminescent backbone. The crystals of Tb-MOF are ground, and the powdered samples are incubated in HCl aqueous solutions with pH ranging from 7 to 2. As shown in Figure b, the solid-state emission intensity of the acid-treated samples gradually decreased in acidic conditions and has a linear response (R 2 = 0.9917) to the pH from 2-7 and the highest value was obtained with pH = 7 solution. The fluorescence sensitivity to the pH could result from the pendent pyridyl groups in the framework. The protonation of the nitrogen atom of these pyridine units would change their electron withdrawing ability, which may be responsible for the decrease of intensity of luminescence at low pH. To further explore the possible mechanism, the ion chromatography of the hydrochloric acid-treated solid-state samples is measured. In the initial samples, Cl- and NO3 - ions as guest anions balance the charges of the cationic framework. The results of ion chromatography revealed the gradual increase of Cl- ions and almost invariable content of NO3 - ions in hydrochloric acid-treated solid-state samples with pH ranging from 7 to 2 (Table ). For hydrochloric acid-treated samples, according to the electric neutrality principle, the protonation of the pendent pyridyl group demand for extra anions (Cl-) are being included in the framework from the hydrochloric solution. In other words, the increased Cl- and the invariable NO3 - in acid-treated samples suggested that the protons are captured by pyridyl nitrogen atoms in HCl solutions, which in turn influence the fluorescence of the framework.

elements.content: It is noteworthy that, apart from the above statically pH-dependent luminescent intensity, the photochromic process and the resulting photoswitch of fluorescence are associated with the protonation of terbium-organic frameworks, which prolong the response time to irradiation. For example, the response time is as long as 80 min for the samples treated by acid solution with pH = 2, whereas it is only 25 min for the pristine ones.
elements.clean_text: It is noteworthy that, apart from the above statically pH-dependent luminescent intensity, the photochromic process and the resulting photoswitch of fluorescence are associated with the protonation of terbium-organic frameworks, which prolong the response time to irradiation. For example, the response time is as long as 80 min for the samples treated by acid solution with pH = 2, whereas it is only 25 min for the pristine ones.

(a) Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) profiles for simulated and Tb-MOF samples soaked in boiling water and aqueous solutions with pH values of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7. (b) The linear variation of the emission (542 nm) intensity for Tb-MOF treated by HCl aqueous solutions with pH ranging from 7 to 2.
elements.clean_text: 6  (a) Powder X-ray diffraction (XRD) profiles for simulated and Tb-MOF samples soaked in boiling water and aqueous solutions with pH values of 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7. (b) The linear variation of the emission (542 nm) intensity for Tb-MOF treated by HCl aqueous solutions with pH ranging from 7 to 2.

elements.content: In this contribution, a novel Tb-MOF material is assembled by viologen functionalized m-benzenedicarboxylate ligand, 1-(3,5-dicarboxybenzyl)-4,4′-bipyridinium chloride, and terbium­(III) ion. Photochromic transformation from bright yellow to dark green with sunlight or UV light is observed due to the viologen unit of the ligand. Moreover, electron/energy transfer from inorganic fluorescent SBUs to organic photochromic component, thus leading to the modulation of the emission intensity by irradiation. More interestingly, the protonation degree of the pyridine ring can be reflected by the luminescent intensity of terbium­(III). In all, interconnected multiphotofunctionality, namely photochromism, photomodulated fluorescence, and luminescent pH sensing, are realized in the title Tb-MOF. So, the rational design of organic linker and choosing metal nodes can confer the resultant MOFs with specific functionality, which would promote the development of applications-oriented materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

In this contribution, a novel Tb-MOF material is assembled by viologen functionalized m-benzenedicarboxylate ligand, 1-(3,5-dicarboxybenzyl)-4,4'-bipyridinium chloride, and terbium(III) ion. Photochromic transformation from bright yellow to dark green with sunlight or UV light is observed due to the viologen unit of the ligand. Moreover, electron/energy transfer from inorganic fluorescent SBUs to organic photochromic component, thus leading to the modulation of the emission intensity by irradiation. More interestingly, the protonation degree of the pyridine ring can be reflected by the luminescent intensity of terbium(III). In all, interconnected multiphotofunctionality, namely photochromism, photomodulated fluorescence, and luminescent pH sensing, are realized in the title Tb-MOF. So, the rational design of organic linker and choosing metal nodes can confer the resultant MOFs with specific functionality, which would promote the development of applications-oriented materials.

elements.content: Experimental details, structural refinement, powder X-ray diffraction, thermal analysis, IR spectrum, additional figures, crystallographic table, and CIF files. This material is available free of charge via the Internet at http://pubs.acs.org.

metadata.title:
Novel Tb-MOF Embedded with Viologen Species for Multi-Photofunctionality:
Photochromism, Photomodulated Fluorescence, and Luminescent pH Sensing
